civilopediaText.text: The modern Albanian state was established in 1912, following centuries of Ottoman rule. After a period of political instability, Ahmet Zogu, who would later crown himself King Zog I, rose to power and transformed Albania from a feudal principality into a modern nation-state.

King Zog I ruled Albania from 1928 to 1939. During his reign, he implemented numerous reforms including the adoption of a civil code, the establishment of a national bank, and significant infrastructure improvements. Despite criticisms of his authoritarian style, he is credited with bringing stability to Albania during a turbulent period in European history.

Albania's geography is predominantly mountainous, with the Albanian Alps in the north and various mountain ranges throughout the country. This rugged terrain has historically provided natural defenses and shaped the resilient character of the Albanian people.

The double-headed eagle is the national symbol of Albania, representing pride, strength, and the country's storied history. It appears on the Albanian flag, symbolizing the nation's sovereignty and endurance through centuries of challenges.

Your revelations gathered in the Holy Quran formed the basis of Islamic theology and brought unity to the Arabian Peninsula. Through wisdom and faith, you transformed a collection of warring tribes into a powerful nation.
startIntroPart2: Prophet Muhammad, your people look to you once more for guidance. Can you unite the faithful under one banner and build a civilization that will stand the test of time?

civilopediaText.title: History
civilopediaText.description: Arabia emerged from the Arabian Peninsula where, in the 7th century CE, the Prophet Muhammad united the warring Arab tribes under the banner of Islam. From humble beginnings in Mecca and Medina, the Islamic Caliphate expanded rapidly through conquest and conversion, eventually stretching from the Iberian Peninsula to the Indus River Valley.

civilopediaText.title: Muhammad
civilopediaText.description: Born in Mecca around 570 CE, Muhammad received divine revelations beginning at age 40, which formed the basis of the Quran. Initially persecuted, he fled to Medina (the Hijra) in 622 CE, marking the beginning of the Islamic calendar. Muhammad's leadership united the Arab tribes through a combination of diplomatic skill, military prowess, and religious authority.

civilopediaText.title: Arabian Golden Age
civilopediaText.description: The Islamic Golden Age saw unprecedented advances in science, mathematics, medicine, astronomy, and philosophy. While Europe languished in the Dark Ages, Arabian scholars preserved ancient Greek texts and made revolutionary discoveries in algebra, optics, and medicine. The House of Wisdom in Baghdad became the intellectual center of the medieval world.

civilopediaText.title: Trade Networks
civilopediaText.description: Arabian merchants established vast trade networks connecting Europe, Africa, and Asia. Caravans crossed deserts carrying spices, textiles, precious metals, and knowledge. Arabian sailors dominated Indian Ocean trade routes, using advanced navigational techniques including the astrolabe.

name: Babylon
startIntroPart1: May the blessings of heaven be upon you, King Nebuchadnezzar II of Babylon. You rule over the mighty city of Babylon, nestled along the mighty Euphrates River. Babylon became the most important city in Mesopotamia around 1792 BCE, when Hammurabi, the great lawgiver, transformed it into a thriving city-state.
startIntroPart2: O great king, your empire fell to the mighty Persians, and then to the Greeks, until the once-proud city was left to the sands. But now your people call for you to rebuild the hanging gardens and the mighty walls of your city! Will you answer their call, great Nebuchadnezzar? Will you restore Babylon to greatness? Will you build a civilization that will stand the test of time?

civilopediaText.text: History

Ancient Greece, which flourished from the archaic period of the 8th century BCE to the end of antiquity around 600 CE, was a civilization that originated in the Mediterranean region and today constitutes the foundation of Western civilization.

Greece reached its apex during the Classical period, particularly during the 'Golden Age' of Athens under the leadership of Pericles (495-429 BCE). This period saw unprecedented advances in philosophy, literature, art, architecture, mathematics, and science.

Unlike many ancient civilizations, Greece was not a single unified empire but rather a collection of independent city-states (poleis) each with its own laws, customs, and governance. The most prominent were Athens, known for its democratic system and cultural achievements, and Sparta, renowned for its military prowess.

Under Pericles, Athens experienced its greatest cultural and political flourishing. The Parthenon and other architectural marvels were constructed, playwrights like Sophocles and Euripides produced their masterpieces, and philosophers like Socrates laid the foundations for Western philosophy.

Greek influence spread widely through colonization and the conquests of Alexander the Great. Though eventually conquered by Rome, Greek culture, language, and ideas continued to shape the ancient world and beyond, leaving an indelible mark on human civilization.
Factoids
The ancient Olympic Games were held every four years in Olympia to honor Zeus, beginning in 776 BCE.
Ancient Greek democracy, established in Athens around 508 BCE, was direct rather than representative - eligible citizens voted on legislation and executive bills themselves.
The Parthenon, dedicated to the goddess Athena, was completed in 432 BCE and is considered the epitome of Classical Greek architecture.
Greek philosophers such as Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle established the foundations of Western philosophy and scientific thinking.
The Greek alphabet, developed around 800 BCE, was derived from the Phoenician alphabet and became the ancestor of Latin and Cyrillic scripts used throughout the world today.
Pericles' famous Funeral Oration, as recorded by Thucydides, remains one of the most profound statements of democratic values and civic duty in Western political thought.

name: Umayyad Caliphate
startIntroPart1: May Allah's blessings be upon you, Caliph Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan, fifth ruler of the Umayyad Caliphate. Under your wise leadership, the empire expanded to its greatest territorial extent, stretching from Spain to India. Your administrative reforms centralized power and standardized the currency throughout the realm.
startIntroPart2: Your greatest achievement stands tall in Jerusalem - the magnificent Dome of the Rock, the first great masterpiece of Islamic architecture. The Arabic language flourished during your reign, becoming the administrative language of the entire caliphate. Great Caliph, your people await your guidance once more. Will you build an empire that spans continents and leaves monuments for the ages?

attacked: You dare attack the Caliphate? Your insolence shall be punished severely.
defeated: The Umayyad banner falls today, but our legacy shall never be forgotten by history.

civilopediaText.text: History

The Umayyad Caliphate was the second of the four major caliphates established after the death of Prophet Muhammad. It was ruled by the Umayyad dynasty, who first came to power under the third caliph, Uthman ibn Affan, but it was not until Muawiyah I became caliph after the end of the First Muslim Civil War in 661 CE that the Umayyads established dynastic rule.

Under the Umayyads, the Islamic empire grew to become one of the largest the world had yet seen, incorporating North Africa, the Middle East, parts of Central Asia, and the Iberian Peninsula. Their rule saw the transformation of the caliphate from a religious entity to an imperial power.
Abd al-Malik

Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan, who ruled from 685 to 705 CE, was the fifth Umayyad caliph and is regarded as the second founder of the Umayyad Caliphate due to his extensive reforms. He centralized government administration, established Arabic as the official language of administration, and reformed the currency by introducing a standard Islamic coinage system.

His most visible legacy is the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem, completed in 691 CE, which remains one of the oldest and most recognizable Islamic monuments. Abd al-Malik's reign represented the high point of Umayyad power, with territorial expansion reaching its maximum extent.
Legacy

The Umayyad Caliphate lasted until 750 CE when it was overthrown by the Abbasid Revolution. However, a branch of the family escaped to Al-Andalus (Iberia) and established the Emirate of Córdoba, which later became the Caliphate of Córdoba, continuing the Umayyad legacy in the West until the early 11th century.

The Umayyad period saw significant cultural and architectural developments, including the construction of the Great Mosque of Damascus. They established an efficient taxation system and postal service, and their patronage of arts and sciences laid groundwork for the later Islamic Golden Age.

startIntroPart2: President Lincoln, your people look to you once more to guide this great nation. Can you uphold the principles of liberty and forge a legacy that will stand the test of time?

civilopediaText.text: The United States of America was founded in 1776 when thirteen British colonies declared their independence. After winning the Revolutionary War under George Washington, the new nation expanded across North America through territorial acquisitions and settlement, eventually stretching from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

Abraham Lincoln, the 16th President of the United States, led the nation through its greatest crisis: the Civil War (1861-1865). Born in a log cabin in Kentucky in 1809, Lincoln rose from humble beginnings to become a lawyer and politician. Elected president in 1860, his victory triggered the secession of Southern states over the issue of slavery.

Lincoln's determination to preserve the Union and his moral opposition to slavery guided his presidency. The Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 declared slaves in Confederate states to be free, transforming the war into a struggle for liberation. Despite tremendous bloodshed, Lincoln maintained his resolve, eventually leading the Union to victory.

Lincoln's second inaugural address, with its call for "malice toward none, with charity for all," outlined his vision for national reconciliation. Tragically, he was assassinated in April 1865, just days after the Confederate surrender at Appomattox Court House.

The United States emerged from the World Wars as a global superpower. The American economy, culture, and military have profoundly shaped the modern world. While facing ongoing challenges including social inequality and political polarization, the ideals of liberty and self-government established by the nation's founders continue to inspire people worldwide.
